questions.text: What type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in the pathogenesis of pemphigus vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Pemphigus vulgaris is mediated by IgG autoantibodies directed against desmogleins (specifically desmoglein-3 and desmoglein-1), which are adhesion molecules in desmosomes. This antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction classifies it as a Type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Type II hypersensitivity is an antibody-mediated immune response where IgG or IgM antibodies target antigens on the surface of cells or extracellular matrix, leading to cellular destruction, dysfunction, or inflammation.

Examples:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Graves disease
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

The pathogenesis of pemphigus revolves around the formation of antibodies anti dsg1 and anti dsg3, and antibodies binding to the antigen dsg1 and dsg3 at their site.

This mechanism is explained in type 2 hypersensitivity reaction.

Explanation of other options:

Type 1 (Option B): Pemphigus vulgaris is not a Type I hypersensitivity reaction because it does not involve IgE antibodies or mast cell degranulation, which are the hallmarks of immediate allergic responses such as anaphylaxis, urticaria, or allergic rhinitis. In contrast, pemphigus vulgaris is mediated by IgG, not IgE, and there is no rapid onset histamine-mediated response.

Type 3 (Option C): Pemphigus Vulgaris is not a Type III hypersensitivity reaction, which is characterized by the formation and deposition of immune complexes (antigen-antibody aggregates) in tissues, leading to complement activation and neutrophil recruitment as seen in systemic lupus erythematosus or serum sickness. Pemphigus vulgaris does not involve circulating immune complexes or their deposition in tissues; instead, antibodies directly target components of the skin

Type 4 (Option D): Pemphigus Vulgaris is not a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which is cell-mediated and involves T lymphocytes, not antibodies. Type IV reactions are delayed (occurring over 48–72 hours) and include conditions such as contact dermatitis and tuberculin skin reactions

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with multiple painful erosions in his oral cavity and flaccid blisters on his trunk that rupture easily. Histopathology reveals intraepidermal acantholysis, and direct immunofluorescence shows intercellular IgG deposition in a "fishnet" pattern. Which of the following is the principal antigen targeted in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • The diagnosis in this case is Pemphigus Vulgaris. Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by IgG autoantibodies against desmoglein 3, a cadherin-type cell adhesion protein found in desmosomes of mucosal and lower epidermal layers.
  • Mucosal involvement is a key clinical feature, and when only desmoglein 3 is involved, oral erosions predominate. When both desmoglein 1 and 3 are involved, skin and mucosal lesions occur.

The hallmark histological feature is suprabasal acantholysis, and direct immunofluorescence reveals intercellular IgG deposition in a fishnet or lace-like pattern.

Explanation of Other Options:

Desmoglein 1 (Option A): Primarily involved in pemphigus foliaceus, which presents with superficial blisters and no mucosal involvement.

Desmoglein 2 (Option B): Found in other tissues like the heart; not a primary target in any pemphigus variant.

Desmoglein 4 (Option D): Involved in hair follicle adhesion; mutations can lead to hypotrichosis, but not pemphigus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with multiple superficial, crusted erosions on her chest and scalp. There is no involvement of the oral mucosa. On biopsy, there is acantholysis in the superficial epidermis with subcorneal splits. What is the principal antigen involved in this condition ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of superficial, crusted erosions on the chest and scalp with no mucosal involvement, along with histology showing subcorneal acantholysis, is characteristic of pemphigus foliaceus.
  • This autoimmune blistering disorder is caused by IgG autoantibodies directed against desmoglein 1, a cadherin-type adhesion molecule found predominantly in the superficial layers of the epidermis. Because desmoglein 1 is not significantly expressed in mucosal epithelium, patients with pemphigus foliaceus typically lack mucosal lesions, which helps distinguish it from pemphigus vulgaris.Pemphigus foliaceus (PF) is an autoimmune skin disorder characterized by the loss of intercellular adhesion of keratinocytes in the upper parts of the epidermis (acantholysis), resulting in the formation of superficial blisters. Superficial blisters in pemphigus foliaceus are induced by IgG autoantibodies directed against desmoglein 1, expressed mainly in the granular layer of the epidermis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Desmoglein 2 (Option B):

Desmoglein 2 is widely expressed in cardiac tissue, the gastrointestinal tract, and basal epidermal layers, but it is not a primary target in any form of pemphigus. Its role is more structural and less involved in the pathogenesis of cutaneous autoimmune blistering diseases.

Desmoglein 3 (Option C):

Desmoglein 3 is the main antigen involved in pemphigus vulgaris, particularly in patients who present with mucosal erosions. It is located in the lower layers of the epidermis and mucous membranes. Since pemphigus foliaceus typically lacks mucosal involvement and affects the upper epidermis, desmoglein 3 is not implicated in its pathogenesis.

Desmoplakin (Option D):

Desmoplakin is a component of desmosomal plaques, playing a role in anchoring intermediate filaments to desmosomal cadherins like desmogleins. However, it is not a target of autoantibodies in any known pemphigus variant. It's important for desmosome structure but not involved in autoimmune blistering diseases.

questions.text: In Pemphigus Foliaceus, split occurs in which layer?
questions.solution:
Explanation 

Pemphigus foliaceus (PF) is an autoimmune skin disorder characterized by acantholysis in the upper parts of the epidermis, resulting in Subcorneal split and formation of superficial blisters. Superficial blisters in pemphigus foliaceus are induced by IgG autoantibodies directed against desmoglein 1, expressed mainly in the granular layer of the epidermis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Spinous (Option B):

The spinous layer refers to the stratum spinosum, a deeper part of the epidermis. Acantholysis at this level is not typical for pemphigus foliaceus. Instead, it's more consistent with other blistering conditions like early stages of pemphigus vulgaris. In pemphigus foliaceus, the split is more superficial, just below the stratum corneum.

Dermo-epidermal junction (Option C):

Splits at the dermo-epidermal junction occur in subepidermal blistering disorders, such as bullous pemphigoid, epidermolysis bullosa acquisita, and dermatitis herpetiformis. These conditions involve autoantibodies against components of the basement membrane zone, not desmosomal cadherins like in pemphigus foliaceus.

Suprabasal (Option D):

A suprabasal split is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris, where acantholysis occurs just above the basal layer due to antibodies against desmoglein 3 (and sometimes desmoglein 1). In contrast, pemphigus foliaceus targets desmoglein 1, which is more superficially located, resulting in a subcorneal split

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with flaccid blisters and painful erosions on her trunk and oral mucosa. Histopathological examination of a skin biopsy reveals loss of cohesion between keratinocytes and the presence of freely floating keratinocytes. In this patientâ€™s condition, acantholysis is primarily seen in which of the following skin layers?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acantholysis refers to the loss of intercellular connections between keratinocytes, leading to intraepidermal cleft formation. This is a hallmark of diseases like pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus, both of which are intraepidermal blistering disorders. It does not occur in the dermis, dermo-epidermal junction, or subcutaneous tissue, which are typically involved in subepidermal blistering conditions like bullous pemphigoid or epidermolysis bullosa.

Explanation of Other options:

Dermis (Option B):

The dermis is not involved in the pathogenesis of pemphigus. Acantholysis does not occur in the dermis, as it lacks keratinocytes.

Dermo-epidermal junction (Option C):

This area is affected in subepidermal blistering diseases such as bullous pemphigoid, but it is not the site of acantholysis, which is confined to the epidermis in pemphigus.

Subcutaneous tissue (Option D):

The subcutaneous tissue is located below the dermis and is not involved in acantholytic processes. It may be affected in deeper infections or inflammatory conditions but not in pemphigus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with painful oral ulcers and multiple flaccid blisters on her chest and back that rupture easily. On examination, several erosions with surrounding erythema are noted. A Tzanck smear prepared from the base of a fresh blister reveals the following findings. Based on the clinical presentation and bedside test findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Tzanck smear in this case shows acantholytic cells, which are rounded, detached keratinocytes resulting from the loss of desmosomal adhesion. This finding is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by IgG antibodies against desmoglein 3 (and sometimes desmoglein 1), leading to suprabasal intraepidermal acantholysis. Clinically, it presents with flaccid blisters and painful oral mucosal erosions.
  • Investigations in Pemphigus Vulgaris:
    • Tzanck Smear: Shows acantholytic (rounded) keratinocytes.
    • Skin Biopsy (H&E): Reveals suprabasal clefting with "row of tombstone" basal cells.
    • Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF): Shows intercellular IgG deposition in a "fishnet" or "chicken wire" pattern throughout the epidermis. It is the investigation of choice

Explanation of Other Options:

Bullous pemphigoid (Option A):

This condition is characterized by tense bullae and subepidermal blistering. Tzanck smear typically does not show acantholytic cells, as the blisters occur below the epidermis, where keratinocytes are not separated.

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option B):

This presents with grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces and is associated with gluten sensitivity. Histologically, it shows neutrophilic microabscesses in dermal papillae, not acantholysis. Tzanck smear is not helpful in this diagnosis.

Herpes zoster (Option D):

Tzanck smear in herpes zoster shows multinucleated giant cells, not acantholytic cells. Clinically, it presents with painful, grouped vesicles in a dermatomal distribution, without mucosal involvement or flaccid bullae.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with multiple flaccid blisters on his trunk and painful erosions in the oral mucosa. On examination, one of the intact bullae is gently pressed laterally at its margin. The bulla is observed to extend into the adjacent uninvolved skin as pressure is applied. This clinical maneuver is best described as the elicitation of which of the following signs?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The maneuver described, where lateral pressure on the edge of an intact bulla causes it to spread, is known as the Bullae spread sign, also called the Lutz sign. This sign suggests that the blister is located within the epidermis, as seen in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris. It helps distinguish intraepidermal blisters from subepidermal ones, which are usually tense and don't spread as easily.

Pemphigus Vulgaris:

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic, potentially life-threatening autoimmune blistering disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, characterized by the production of autoantibodies against desmoglein 3 (and in some cases, desmoglein 1), leading to loss of intercellular adhesion (acantholysis) in the epidermis.

Age of Presentation:

  • Most commonly affects adults aged 40-60 years.
  • Rare in children and older elderly individuals.
  • No strong sex predilection, though some studies show a slight female predominance.

Sites Affected:

  • Oral mucosa: Most common initial site (50-70% of cases).
  • Scalp, face, neck, upper chest, axillae, groin, back, and intertriginous areas.
  • Genital and conjunctival mucosa may also be involved.

Lesions:

Types:

  1. Flaccid bullae - Fragile blisters that rupture easily.
  2. Erosions - Result from ruptured bullae; painful and often secondarily infected.
  3. Crusted plaques - Especially on scalp and trunk.
  4. Mucosal ulcers - Irregularly shaped, shallow erosions particularly in the oral cavity.

Typical progression:

Flaccid blister → Rupture → Painful erosion → Healing with post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (no scarring).

Clinical Signs:

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Nikolsky sign (Option A): Involves applying lateral pressure to normal-appearing skin, leading to exfoliation of the epidermis. It reflects a loss of intercellular adhesion and is also positive in pemphigus vulgaris.

Asboe-Hansen sign (Option C): Also called the bulla extension sign, it involves pressing on the center of a bulla to see if it extends peripherally. It's subtly different from Bullae spread sign but also seen in pemphigus.

Hutchinson's sign (Option D): Refers to vesicles on the tip of the nose indicating nasociliary branch involvement in herpes zoster ophthalmicus. It is unrelated to bullae mechanics.

questions.text: Nikolsky sign is positive in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Nikolsky sign is considered positive when gentle lateral pressure on normal-appearing skin causes the epidermis to shear off, indicating a loss of cohesion between epidermal cells. It is typically positive in conditions with intraepidermal or superficial epidermal clefting.

Positive Nikolsky sign is seen in:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris - due to autoantibody-mediated acantholysis (loss of intercellular connections in the epidermis). (Option A ruled out)
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) - due to widespread keratinocyte necrosis from drug-induced damage. (Option C ruled out)
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) - due to exfoliative toxin-mediated cleavage within the granular layer of epidermis. (Option D ruled out)

In bullous pemphigoid, the blisters are subepidermal and tense, meaning the epidermis remains more structurally intact. The autoantibodies target components of the basement membrane (BP180, BP230), leading to blistering below the epidermis, which does not result in easy shearing of the skin.

questions.text: Match the following Vesiculobullous disorders with the level of their skin split
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pemphigus foliaceus → Subcorneal (B):
    This is a superficial variant of pemphigus where the split occurs just below the stratum corneum due to anti-desmoglein 1 antibodies.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris → Suprabasal (C):
    The split occurs above the basal layer of the epidermis due to anti-desmoglein 3 (and sometimes Dsg1) antibodies, leading to a suprabasal cleft.
  • Bullous pemphigoid → Subepidermal (A):
    This condition involves antibodies against BP180/BP230 in the basement membrane, causing a split below the entire epidermis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with flaccid blisters on her trunk and multiple painful erosions in her oral mucosa. A skin biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris. Which of the following histological features is not typically seen in pemphigus vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Basal cell degeneration refers to damage or vacuolization of the basal layer of the epidermis, often accompanied by apoptotic keratinocytes (Civatte bodies) and interface dermatitis. This change indicates injury to the dermal-epidermal junction, typically caused by immune-mediated attack on basal keratinocytes.

It is not a feature of pemphigus vulgaris, which involves autoantibodies against desmoglein 3, leading to suprabasal acantholysis, with the basal cells remaining intact and attached to the dermis via hemidesmosomes. This preserved basal layer forms the classic "row of tombstones" appearance in histology.

Basal cell degeneration is instead seen in conditions such as:

  • Lichen planus
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Graft-versus-host disease

These conditions are characterized by interface dermatitis, which is distinctly different from the intraepidermal blistering of pemphigus.

Explanation of other options:

Acanthosis (Option A):

Acanthosis refers to thickening of the epidermis, particularly of the stratum spinosum. While not a primary diagnostic feature, mild acanthosis may be observed in chronic or resolving lesions of pemphigus vulgaris. It is considered a secondary, reactive change and does not contribute directly to blister formation.

Acantholysis (Option B):

Acantholysis is the hallmark histopathological finding in pemphigus vulgaris. It refers to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes due to autoantibodies targeting desmoglein 3. This leads to suprabasal intraepidermal clefting and is responsible for blister formation. Acantholytic cells may be seen floating freely in the blister cavity.

Dyskeratosis (Option C):

Dyskeratosis denotes premature and abnormal keratinization of individual keratinocytes. In pemphigus vulgaris, focal dyskeratotic cells may occasionally be present, especially near blister cavities. However, it is a nonspecific finding and not essential for diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic investigations can distinguish between pemphigus vulgaris and foliaceous?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A histopathological examination of a skin biopsy helps distinguish between pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus based on the level of epidermal split:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris: Suprabasal split with a "row of tombstones" appearance.
  • Pemphigus foliaceus: Subcorneal split (just beneath the stratum corneum

Explanation of other options:

Direct immunofluorescence (Option A): While both PV and PF show intercellular IgG deposits in a "fishnet" pattern, the pattern does not differentiate the depth of split or subtype. It confirms pemphigus but not the exact type.

Tzanck smear (Option B): This detects acantholytic cells in both PV and PF. It is supportive of a pemphigus diagnosis but is nonspecific and cannot differentiate between the subtypes.

Anti-desmoglein antibody level (Option C): This test can suggest the diagnosis, as:

  • PV is associated with anti-Dsg3 (and sometimes Dsg1)
  • PF is associated with anti-Dsg1 only.

However, antibody profiles can overlap, and levels may not always correlate with clinical subtype. Therefore, histology remains more definitive.

questions.text: The floating acantholytic cells seen in the histopathology image are derived from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The floating acantholytic cells seen in pemphigus vulgaris are keratinocytes that have lost cohesion due to the destruction of desmosomes, which are primarily found in the stratum granulosum. These cells round up and detach, becoming the hallmark acantholytic cells found in the blister cavity.

  • In histopathology, this loss of cohesion occurs just above the basal layer (i.e., suprabasal), involving cells from the stratum granulosum.
  • The stratum spinosum lies below the granulosum and is not the primary layer involved in acantholysis in pemphigus vulgaris or foliaceus.(Option A ruled out)
  • The stratum basale remains attached to the dermis via hemidesmosomes. (Option D ruled out)
  • The stratum corneum is anucleate and keratinized, not a source of viable acantholytic cells. (Option C ruled out)

It is also called as Senear Usher Syndrome

questions.text: All of the following are true about pemphigus erythematosus except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pemphigus erythematosus, also known as Senear-Usher syndrome, (Option C ruled out) is a localized, milder variant of pemphigus foliaceus.(Option B ruled out) It is an autoimmune vesiculobullous disorder where autoantibodies target desmoglein 1, a cadherin-type adhesion molecule in the superficial epidermis. PE uniquely shows overlap features of both pemphigus foliaceus and lupus erythematosus, making it a hybrid or "overlap syndrome." (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: The skin away from the bullae

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with multiple tense bullae and vesicles over her trunk and limbs. You suspect an autoimmune blistering disorder. For direct immunofluorescence (DIF) studies, from which site should the biopsy be taken to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In autoimmune blistering disorders, a biopsy should be taken from the normal skin around the bulla. This area is called the perilesional skin, and it is the ideal site for performing direct immunofluorescence (DIF).

  • DIF detects in vivo-bound autoantibodies and complement deposits (e.g., IgG, C3) in the skin.
  • Taking a biopsy from normal-appearing skin within 1 cm of a lesion ensures that the antigen-antibody complexes are intact and not degraded by inflammation or blistering.

Explanation of other options:

Fresh Bulla (Option A):

The skin at blister site is usually damaged, necrotic, or inflamed, leading to disruption of antigen-antibody complexes. As a result, DIF may show false-negative or inconclusive results.

Skin away from the bullae (Option C):

DIF relies on the presence of in situ antibody deposits, which are usually found in the skin adjacent to active lesions. Skin sampled far from the lesion may not contain immune deposits, especially in localized disease, increasing the risk of a false-negative DIF.

Can be taken from anywhere (Option D):

DIF is site-dependent. Sampling from the wrong site (e.g., necrotic, ulcerated, or distant unaffected skin) may yield non-diagnostic or misleading results.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with tense bullae on his lower limbs and trunk. There is no oral mucosal involvement. You are considering a differential diagnosis between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid. What is the key differentiating factor between the two conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Immunopathology is the most important differentiating factor between pemphigus and bullous pemphigoid, particularly when confirmed via direct immunofluorescence (DIF):

  • Pemphigus vulgaris: Autoantibodies are directed against desmoglein 3 (and sometimes desmoglein 1). DIF shows intercellular IgG deposition in a "fishnet" pattern in the epidermis.
  • Bullous pemphigoid: Autoantibodies are directed against hemidesmosomal proteins BP180 (type XVII collagen) and BP230. DIF shows linear IgG and/or C3 deposition along the basement membrane zone (BMZ).

Explanation of other options:

Presence of an autoimmune component (Option A): Incorrect, as both conditions are autoimmune blistering diseases. They differ in the target antigens and level of skin involvement, not in the presence of autoimmunity itself.

Mucous membrane involvement (Option B): Although pemphigus vulgaris typically involves mucosa and bullous pemphigoid usually spares it, this is not a consistent or reliable differentiator in all cases. Mucosal involvement can occasionally occur in bullous pemphigoid too, especially in elderly patients.

Disease management (Option C): Treatment regimens may overlap, including the use of corticosteroids and immunosuppressants. Hence, management is not a key differentiating factor. The distinction lies primarily in the immunopathological findings.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient was started on a medication by his physician. A few weeks later, he developed shallow skin erosions with crust formation. There is no involvement of the scalp or mucous membranes. A clinical sign, as shown in image, is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture described is most consistent with Pemphigus foliaceous, a superficial form of pemphigus that primarily affects the upper epidermis.

  • Pemphigus foliaceus is a superficial autoimmune blistering disease involving autoantibodies directed against desmoglein 1, which is predominantly expressed in the upper layers of the epidermis.
  • The disease often presents with shallow erosions and crusting, typically without mucosal or scalp involvement. A positive Nikolsky sign (where the superficial skin shears off with lateral pressure) supports the diagnosis due to intraepidermal acantholysis.
  • Drug-induced pemphigus foliaceus has been associated with certain medications like
  • Captopril
  • Diclofenac
  • Rifampin
  • Cephalosporins
  • Nifedipine
  • Aspirin
  • Propranolol

Explanation of other options:

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option A):

Involves deeper epidermal layers (desmoglein 3, ±1), commonly presents with flaccid blisters and painful mucosal erosions, especially in the oral cavity. In this case, mucosa is spared, making PV less likely.

Bullous pemphigoid (Option C):

Typically presents with tense blisters on an erythematous base, often in the elderly. Nikolsky sign is negative, and lesions are deeper and subepidermal, not superficial erosions and crusts.

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option D):

Presents with intensely pruritic grouped vesicles and papules, commonly on extensor surfaces, and is associated with celiac disease. Nikolsky sign is not seen, and crusted erosions in this distribution without mucosal involvement are not characteristic.

questions.text: A patient presents with blistering skin lesions. To differentiate between pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus by cutaneous examination, which of the following would be the most helpful?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Pemphigus vulgaris typically involves both skin and mucous membranes, with painful erosions commonly seen in the oral mucosa. In contrast, pemphigus foliaceus usually spares mucous membranes and involves only the superficial layers of the skin.

Therefore, the presence or absence of mucosal involvement is a key clinical differentiator between the two.

Explanation of other options:

Examination of palms and soles (Option B)

The palms and soles are typically not involved in either pemphigus vulgaris or pemphigus foliaceus. Involvement of these areas is more common in other conditions such as bullous pemphigoid, erythema multiforme, or hand-foot-mouth disease. Thus, this examination does not help in differentiating between the two pemphigus variants.

Examination of nails (Option C)

Nail involvement is not a characteristic feature of either pemphigus vulgaris or pemphigus foliaceus. While rare nail changes can occur in autoimmune blistering diseases, they are not specific enough to differentiate between these two conditions.

Wood's lamp examination of bullae (Option D)

Wood's lamp is used to detect fluorescence in conditions like tinea capitis, erythrasma, vitiligo, and porphyrias. The bullae seen in pemphigus vulgaris or foliaceus do not fluoresce under Wood's light. Therefore, this test has no diagnostic value in differentiating between the two.

questions.text: Which of the following is the rarest variety of pemphigus
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pemphigus vegetans is the rarest variant of pemphigus. It is considered a rare clinical subtype of pemphigus vulgaris and is characterized by the formation of vegetating plaques in flexural areas such as the groin, axillae, and inframammary folds.

Unlike the typical flaccid bullae of pemphigus vulgaris, these lesions are hypertrophic, wart-like, and exudative.

Two clinical subtypes are recognized:

  • Neumann type: More severe with ulcerative lesions
  • Hallopeau type: Milder with pustules and crusts

Despite being part of the pemphigus spectrum, pemphigus vegetans accounts for only a very small percentage of cases, making it the rarest.

Explanation of other options:

Pemphigus Vulgaris (Option A):

Pemphigus vulgaris is the most common variant of pemphigus. It presents with flaccid blisters and erosions that involve both the skin and mucous membranes, particularly the oral mucosa. . Although it can be severe and life-threatening if untreated, it is far more prevalent than pemphigus vegetans.

Pemphigus Foliaceus (Option C):

Pemphigus foliaceus is a superficial form of pemphigus in which the autoantibodies target desmoglein 1. It is more common than pemphigus vegetans and can be endemic in certain regions such as rural South America, where the form known as fogo selvagem is observed.

Pemphigus Erythematosus (Option D):

Pemphigus erythematosus, also known as Senear-Usher syndrome, is a localized variant of pemphigus foliaceus. It typically affects seborrheic areas such as the face and upper chest and may show overlapping features with lupus erythematosus, including positive ANA and lupus band test. Though less common than vulgaris and foliaceus, it is still not as rare as pemphigus vegetans.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of Drug induced Pemphigus EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Drug-induced pemphigus is a well-recognized condition that mimics the clinical and histopathological features of idiopathic pemphigus. It is most often associated with drugs that contain thiol (-SH) groups,

Furosemide is not a well-established cause of drug-induced pemphigus. While it has been associated with a variety of cutaneous adverse drug reactions (e.g., photosensitivity, Stevens-Johnson syndrome), it is not classically linked to pemphigus, especially compared to other thiol and non-thiol drugs.

Causes of Drug Induced Pemphigus:

  • D-Penicillamine (Option A ruled out)
  • Captopril (Option C ruled out)
  • Rifampicin (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with painful mucosal erosions, polymorphic skin lesions, and a history of recent weight loss and malaise. Clinical suspicion of paraneoplastic pemphigus is raised.Which of the following is the most common underlying neoplasm associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paraneoplastic pemphigus (PNP) is most commonly associated with Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, making it the most frequent underlying malignancy in reported cases. PNP is a severe, autoimmune mucocutaneous blistering disorder that occurs in association with various neoplasms, especially lymphoproliferative malignancies.
  • Patients present with painful erosions, particularly on the mucosa, along with polymorphous skin eruptions. The presence of autoantibodies against plakin family proteins and both humoral and cell-mediated immune mechanisms contribute to its pathogenesis. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma remains the most consistently reported hematologic malignancy in association with PNP.

Explanation of Other options:

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (Option A):

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a known but less common hematologic malignancy associated with paraneoplastic pemphigus. It is part of the broader group of B-cell lymphoproliferative disorders involved in PNP, but not the most frequent.

Thymoma (Option C):

Thymoma is a non-hematologic neoplasm occasionally associated with PNP. It may also be linked with other autoimmune syndromes (e.g., myasthenia gravis), but in the context of paraneoplastic pemphigus, its association is rare compared to lymphomas.

Castleman Disease (Option D):

Castleman disease, especially the multicentric variant, is a well-established cause of PNP, particularly in younger patients. However, it is still less common overall than Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. In pediatric or adolescent patients, Castleman disease may even be the leading association, but across all age groups, NHL is more frequent.

questions.text: Pemphigus neonatorum is related to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pemphigus neonatorum is a term historically used to describe a transient blistering skin condition seen in neonates, which clinically resembles pemphigus, but it is actually caused by Staphylococcus aureus infection. It is now more accurately recognized as bullous impetigo in neonates. The blisters result from exfoliative toxins produced by S. aureus, which cleave desmoglein 1, the same molecule targeted in pemphigus foliaceus. The disease presents with superficial, flaccid blisters that rupture easily, usually without systemic toxicity, and it responds well to antibiotics.

Explanation of other options:

Epidermolysis bullosa (Option B):

Epidermolysis bullosa refers to a group of inherited mechanobullous disorders, not an infectious condition. These disorders involve genetic defects in structural proteins of the skin, leading to fragile skin and blistering in response to minor trauma. It is not related to pemphigus neonatorum or bullous impetigo.

Congenital syphilis (Option C):

Congenital syphilis is a systemic infection caused by Treponema pallidum transmitted from mother to child. Though it may present with desquamation and bullous lesions (pemphigus syphiliticus), it has a different pathogenesis and clinical course and is not synonymous with pemphigus neonatorum.

Pemphigus (Option D):

While the name "pemphigus neonatorum" might suggest a connection, true autoimmune pemphigus (like pemphigus vulgaris or foliaceus) is extremely rare in neonates. The blistering seen in pemphigus neonatorum is not due to autoantibodies but due to bacterial toxin-mediated cleavage, thus distinguishing it from pemphigus.
